meanings.definition: Establish or organize as an institution.
meanings.sent1: The government decided to institutionalise the new program to help more people.
meanings.sent2: Universities often institutionalise certain traditions to maintain a sense of history and community.
meanings.sent3: The idea to institutionalise nap time at work was met with mixed reactions.
meanings.sent4: She wanted to institutionalise a culture of kindness in her workplace.
meanings.sent5: The teacher hoped to institutionalise a love for reading in her students.

meanings.definition: Make into or treat as an institution.
meanings.sent1: The family decided to institutionalise their weekly game night as a special tradition.
meanings.sent2: Over time, the small business grew and was institutionalised as a key player in the industry.
meanings.sent3: He jokingly suggested to institutionalise Taco Tuesday at the office.
meanings.sent4: The local artist's work was so influential that it became institutionalised in the art world.
meanings.sent5: The community sought to institutionalise the annual charity event for years to come.

meanings.definition: Place or confine in an institution, especially a mental health facility.
meanings.sent1: The court ordered to institutionalise the patient for further evaluation.
meanings.sent2: In extreme cases, individuals may need to be institutionalised for their own safety.
meanings.sent3: The idea to institutionalise the troublemakers in a separate class was considered.
meanings.sent4: She felt like her creativity was being institutionalised in the rigid environment.
meanings.sent5: The strict rules seemed to institutionalise the students' behavior in the school.
